topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Jerry opens with the core idea of self-honesty in leadership and Lenny introduces Jerry’s background, what the episode will cover, and why it matters.

topics.title: The “complicit” question and personal agency
topics.summary: Jerry explains: “How have I been complicit in creating the conditions I say I don’t want?”—why “complicit” isn’t “responsible,” and how the question restores agency (e.g., busyness as a chosen pattern).

topics.title: The Reboot equation for better leadership
topics.summary: Jerry shares Reboot’s leadership equation—practical skills + radical self-inquiry + shared experiences = enhanced leadership + greater resilience—and ties it to his own history with depression and the goal of not “killing yourself in the process.”

topics.title: The big lie of success and happiness
topics.summary: They discuss how achievement doesn’t automatically create wellbeing; Jerry recounts a 19-year-old’s takeaway (“you don’t have to be an asshole to be successful”) and reframes ambition toward conscious living.

topics.title: Consciousness, ambition, and the “lemon drops” story
topics.summary: Jerry argues the “hack” is consciousness: interrogating what success is supposed to fix. He shares how childhood insecurity shaped his relationship to money and safety, illustrating why leaders must examine their underlying drivers.

topics.title: Fear of self-inquiry and the cost of avoidance
topics.summary: Lenny raises the fear that deep inquiry forces drastic life changes; Jerry reframes it as inevitable baggage that will demand attention later, citing Bruce Springsteen’s decades of therapy and the “price in tears” of avoidance.

topics.title: Practical radical self-inquiry questions to journal
topics.summary: Jerry offers concrete prompts for reflection: what am I not saying, what’s not being heard, what am I not hearing, and the “complicit” question—emphasizing that the best questions are the ones that startle you.

topics.title: Shared experiences: circles, truth-telling, and community
topics.summary: Jerry explains “shared experiences” as honest, held space (e.g., CEO bootcamps, circles) that counters entrepreneurial performative optimism and enables real truth-telling without fixing or judging.

topics.title: Busyness, growth addiction, and imposter syndrome
topics.summary: Using Lenny’s own patterns, Jerry connects constant growth and busyness to soothing an inner “not good enough” voice, and suggests shifting toward “art project” motivation where self-worth isn’t tied to outcomes.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsored segment featuring OneSchema and its FileFeeds 2.0 product for automating messy spreadsheet/file integrations with validation and error reporting.

topics.title: Attachment, comfort, and Buddhist framing of suffering
topics.summary: Jerry uses the Four Noble Truths to explain how attachment to outcomes (money, status, stability) amplifies anxiety; he shares his practice of avoiding reviews and focusing on purpose over validation.

topics.title: Legacy, meaning, and being a “good ancestor”
topics.summary: They debate whether legacy matters (Mike Tyson vs. eulogy framing). Jerry argues legacy is moral responsibility in turbulent times, sharing the toppled oak tree metaphor and the desire to be remembered as caring and kind.

topics.title: AI anxiety and what remains uniquely human
topics.summary: Jerry reflects on AI as a fundamentally different shift than prior tech waves, emphasizing presence and connection as enduring human value; they discuss using LLMs for reflection (journals, meeting transcripts) as a tool that can improve coaching and thinking.
